title: ASX edges higher on IT sector gains
text:
Shares in Xero were up 2.91 per cent, finishing the day at $68.88. While Afterpay added 1.57 per cent to close at $29.1 and Iress 4.62 per cent to close at $12.24.

The energy majors lost ground on Tuesday, following a 0.8 per cent drop in the Brent crude oil price on Monday night to $US 61.53 barrel, and a 1.4 per cent fall in West Texas Intermediate, which fell to $US 55.87.

Excess supply and improved trade sentiment were seen as the main drivers depressing prices.

Among the local energy companies was Woodside, which shed 0.21 per cent to $.344. Origin Energy fell 0.63 per cent to close at $7.94 and Beach Energy lost 2.92 per cent to close at $2.33.

Resources shares provided support for the benchmark lead by BHP. The big miner finished the day at $36.62, up 1.24 per cent and Rio Tinto ended trade at $92.2, up 1.04 per cent.

Fortescue Metals was among the exceptions, dropping 0.55 per cent to $8.96.

Also in mining, lithium stocks notched up a second day of gains. This is in part due to civil unrest disrupting major producers in Chile, according to Canaccord Genuity's head of mining research Reg Spencer.

Advertisement

But after months of oversupply concerns, Mr Spencer added that expectations of planned output reductions may also be providing support and that a change in fortune could be in order.

"Separately, we have seen some significant curtailment in capacity and planned capacity in the lithium space in recent months," he said. "There is a view among some investors that the sector could be approaching a bottom."

Orocobre was one of the better performers among the Australian-listed lithium miners. Shares in the company rose 4.51 per cent to $2.55, up 10.51 per cent so far this week.

Consumer businesses lost ground. Dominos Pizza lost 2.48 per cent to close at $49.54 and a shaky outlook from Bega Cheese saw that company shed 12.47 per cent to $3.965.

The cheese maker released a statement on Tuesday warning of tightening market conditions due to "the effects of the continuing drought and further decreases in total Australian milk production".

Out-of-home advertising business QMS Media posted the biggest rise on Tuesday after a bid for the company by Quadrant Private Equity was unveiled.

The $1.22-per-share deal, first foreshadowed by the AFR's Street Talk on Friday, valued the company's equity at $420.6 million and a total enterprise value of $571.6 million.

Advertisement

QMS shares ended the day just under the offer price at $1.21, up from $1 when it entered a trading halt on Friday. The all-cash offer will also leave shareholders with a final dividend of up to 1.3¢ for the calendar year.

The big banks weighed slightly on the local exchange. Westpac dropped 0.9 per cent to $28.73 and ANZ fell one third of a per cent to close at $27.93.

The event likely to weigh on Australian equities when trade opens on Wednesday is Tuesday evening's speech from the Reserve bank governor Philip Lowe.

The talk from Australia's top central banker is expected to give a read on the RBA's appetite for further rate cuts and the use unconventional monetary policy to support the economy.
description: ASX edges higher with a lift in the IT sector, marking the seventh straight day of gains.
